demonstrators took to the streets
activists prepare a 2nd flotilla to Gaza
leveraging the media's glare against

support for President Obama is kept out
of the public eye there's a sense that
even though people aren't necessarily

don't necessarily want to be seen as

this is Rachel Donadio reporting for the
New York Times in Athens I'm standing
just south of syntagma square the square
in front of the parliament building
where today the Greek parliament is
debating some key austerity measures
that they've been asked to pass in the
next few days before their foreign
lenders will give them the money they
need to stave off bankruptcy there are
huge demonstrations going on today it's
the first day of a two day general
strike called by unions and a couple
hundred metres up I see police
skirmishing with some protesters they're
firing lots of tear gas which is wafting
over the crowds and making its way
slowly south to where I'm standing but
on the edges here there are a lot of
peaceful protesters they've come to just
vent their grievances at a government
they feel has betrayed them Greece has a
pretty healthy tradition of street
protest and this is no exception it's a
country with a particular history it
ended World War two with a civil war it
had a military dictatorship from 1967 to
74 people protested against that and
there's really this tradition of taking
to the streets raising your fists and
the Greek police have traditionally
fired tear gas on these crowds to to
thin them out there's a small
possibility that the austerity measures
will not pass because of dissent within
the ranks of the Socialist Party itself
obviously it's difficult for a socialist
government to push through these
austerity measures that include
essentially going after a unions at the
heart of their constituency so some
lawmakers have said they're considering
voting against them the general sense is
that probably at the end of the day the
government will rally and pass the
measures but it's going to come down to
a few key votes tomorrow for a second
time activists are preparing to counter
the Israeli Navy's blockade of Gaza this
is ethan bronner reporting from
Jerusalem Israel is waiting right now
for a group of boats to set sail
probably in the coming two days their
goal is to challenge Israel's control
over the waters of Gaza over its naval
blockade a year ago there was a similar
group about 6 of them Turkish run and it
did not end well Israel in an effort to
stop those boats boarded the largest of
them met resistance on board and 9
activists on board were killed by
israeli commandos that event actually
caused quite a change in Israel's policy
there was enormous international outrage
there was condemnation of the Security
Council of the United Nations and Israel
as a result starting to allow many more
kinds of goods into Gaza so in a min
hard way while this is a kind of media
circus in the sense that we know that
this these boats are going to be stopped
at scene I'm not going to get through
and we know that they're not bringing
vast amounts of humanitarian aid we do
know at the same time that the challenge
political challenge that the last
flotilla gave to Israel did create a
change on the ground for Gaza and deal
books Evelyn Rusli and andrew ross
sorkin discuss President Obama's
relationship with Wall Street heading
into the 2012 presidential campaign Wall
Street is showing some reluctance to
commit to Obama but they may not be
deserting him in mascot right the
conventional wisdom is somehow that wall
street has completely turned its back on
Obama that they're not supporting him
they're not giving him money they're not
doing anything I think privately despite
all of the rhetoric there's a sense that
even though people aren't necessarily
giving him money so publicly that
privately they may ultimately turn turn
around and vote for in
this environment there's two issues one
is that many of the CEOs themselves as I
said before don't want to be put in a
position where they're looking like
they're supporting somebody who's
obviously coming down on their
businesses in terms of financial reform
and everything else the other side which
is almost ironic is that the idea that
you know Obama and Lloyd Blankfein are
going to be in a you know a photo spread
together as well as one banker said to
me you know isn't good for either of
them but there is some tension between
Wall Street and Obama right how do you
read the pulse today where would you say
you know Wall Street is generally
speaking are they happy with Obama I
think they're privately okay with Obama
yeah I think they're saying it isn't it
hasn't been nearly as bad as it might
have been the other element that's so
interesting is the sort of box Obama's
in which is you know on the left
liberals really believe he hasn't done
enough and on you know the right or
within wall street at least there's this
there's this sense that he's already
done too much and so the question is
where what do you do so how will this
shake out in the next election cycle
well we might not be seeing people jump
in to support people this early in the
race we're going to find out who the
Republican candidate is if it's Mitt
Romney I think that's somebody the wall
street can ultimately live with if it's
michelle bachman i think that's actually
going to be a much tougher sell and you
might see a lot more support for obama
so ultimately I think you're going to
see a lot of money come into this
campaign and you're going to see people
making multiple bets because as they say
in the business they like to hedge their
bets
